Charles and I are lunching tomorrow for the first time in three weeks. He suffered a severe vertigo attack and was hospitalized and had been recuperating at home.

We colored outside the lines a bit by enjoying a bottle of Gramona "Imperial" Gran Reserva 2007. This wine was a different beast compared to those I've purchased from supermarket shelves, which range in style from unremarkable to sparkling kerosene.

In many ways, this reminded us of several Champagnes we've had in the past. Gorgeous light gold color, fine, pearly bubbles, and a yeasty, green-apple and almond dominated nose. As it warmed up, the wine started to show off some savory, grassy, and herbal aromas. We paired it with the recommended pan con tomate (like anyone needs an excuse to eat that) and a main course of turbot fillets pan seared in butter. The filets were served with a ragu-like sauce of tomatoes, shallots, leeks, capers, and marinated green olives. We threw in a dash of red pepper flakes for a faint kick.

The wine paired beautifully, its clean acidity and chalky mineral notes providing a nice contrast to the rich and briny qualities of the main course. Flavors of apple, lemon zest, and brioche toast seemed to dominate, with a touch of honey on the finish. The toasty qualities in particular contributed a depth and persistence that made it a capable match for the bolder flavors of our meal.

We've had a few vintage Cavas before, but they didn't have the richness or finesse possessed by tonight's wine. With Champagne commanding ever higher prices, being able to purchase a gem like this for half the price seems almost criminal. Not that I mind.

How will there be a more of a "huge cut" than a 25% reduction in GDP, a 50% increase in poverty rate for pensioners who can't work to rebuild their lives, a 30% reduction in food consumption, and 50% youth unemployment? Declaring bankruptcy, they're off the troika hook, and whatever money they were going to use to service the debt - 15% of GDP - they can use to invest and stimulate the economy. The euro experiment for Greece in my opinion has failed because the only beneficiaries have been their 1%. The rest are faced with a choice of relinquishing sovereignty or keeping a currency which has done them not much good. Better be poor and have hope than stay poor and lose your country to some North-European right-wing elites.

Actually I would argue that besides medicine, the Greeks absolutely can afford to stop buying them, and would be well-served by a forced sobriety on this matter. Greeks, like those of us in most of the western world, are completely in thrall to consumerism.  I speak of the 20-40% who are not living below the poverty line, of course.  If Greece exits and goes back to the Drachma, we go back to the way things were pre-euro: food (produced inside the country) is cheap, but luxury import goods are expensive.  You'll have to save for some months to buy a stereo again, and probably take the bus instead of a car.  I wonder why Germany doesn't like that idea. The exit, I think, is almost certainly the best option for Greece to remain a sovereign nation and take responsibility for its future.  Greece was a poor country before the Euro -- and there is nothing sustainable about the "new wealth" it has found in the Euro.

What in God"s name is financial repression but a contrived argument by those who want to be paid higher than market interest on their capital. The market is determining interest rates and aggregate demand is still weak and that is why they are low. The U.S. is not Greece and any attempt to link Keynesian economics with the problems in Greece is absolutely wrong. The problems in this country are the result of 35 years of supply-side economics and the experiment has failed. The only free lunch was the one given from the middle class to the wealthy, you know the job creators, that took their tax cuts and created jobs all right - overseas. The American people have to ask themselves how did this happen - how is it that corporate profits are so high (see stock market) and deficits so large - maybe because the profits overseas were not invested back here or taxed? And then there is the subsidy of foreign investment operations known as the defense department which reduces their foreign investment risk. Those things have little to do with Keynesian economics, just plain old fashion greed, corruption and the impact on our middle class is clear to see. That is why aggregate demand hasn't driven up inflation because the middle class hasn't been paid for their productivity gains in decades. So if your upset because you have low investment returns, your right but you got the consequences of failed policy and Keynesian economics had nothing to do - Republicans squandered the surplus.

Greece has been accorded equal respect in the Eurozone, what it fails to understand is that it has to respect that equal accord as well. Demanding that it can continue to let their public employees retire at ca. 55 while the rest of Europe pays for it when they themselves are having to work until 67 is a sticking point to say the least. You should try that one over there and see how many votes you get for it. Allow all state employees in New Hampshire to retire at 55 on same level of benefits as the best in the country and see how long the rest of the country keeps giving them money.

It is clearly in the best interests of Greece and its creditors that all parties return to the negotiating table. I am heartened by indications that Greece, Germany, the IMF and otherss are moving in this direction.

What has been striking to me is that most global financial institutions have been treated with deference as systemically important partners in the international finance system. Greece should be accorded equal respect in the Eurozone.

Bret Winter's obeisance to the troika is utterly foolish, because it is false to history.  Excessive debts have often been forgiven when the creditors decide they want to.  That even applies to private debt, owed by private entities (including persons) to other private entities.  (In fact, forgiveness of debt owed by CEOs to their large companies has been a regular mode of inflating compensation.)  But forget private debt:  public debt owed to public creditors has been forgiven often, when policy dictated that was the best solution for the creditor (in the creditor's opinion, not necessarily an objective or correct one).  So, Bret and the others who ignorantly prate about the sacredness of debt, put the high horse back in the stable and get real.
Baron95, that's a very superficial inference.  You'd have to consider a great deal more than one bit of accounting to come up with a case that carries any conviction.
